headline: GM to Import EV Batteries From China Despite Tariffs
summary: General Motors plans to import batteries from China to power its second-generation Chevrolet Bolt electric vehicle, despite steep tariffs imposed by President Trump. GM will buy the batteries from China’s Contemporary Amperex Technology, one of the world’s largest battery makers, for about two years until GM and its Korean partner, LG Energy Solution, can stand up their own manufacturing of the batteries in the U.

headline: Trump Demanded Intel's CEO Resign. He Isn't the First President to Try Pushing a CEO Out
summary: President Donald Trump demanded the resignation of Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan on Thursday. It's an exceedingly rare move—a U.S. president calling on a private sector executive to pack up their office—but it has happened before.

headline: Trump Admin Supporting Mine-to-Magnet Supply Chain for Rare Earths
summary: General Motors Co. has signed a deal with Texas-based Noveon Magnetics Inc. to secure rare-earth magnets for its full-size pickup trucks and SUVs, marking the third domestic supply contract the automaker has signed related to the critical trade dominated by China. The latest agreement and two others with Las Vegas-based MP Materials Corp. and E-Vac Magnetics, a South Carolina-based unit of Germany's Vacuumschmelze GmbH will allow GM to get the majority of rare-earth magnets it sources directly from domestic suppliers, the Detroit carmaker said Wednesday. Dr Gracelin Baskaran, Director, Critical Minerals Security Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, says the United States is giving all the right signals.

raw.headline: Trump Admin Supporting Mine-to-Magnet Supply Chain for Rare Earths
raw.summary: General Motors Co. has signed a deal with Texas-based Noveon Magnetics Inc. to secure rare-earth magnets for its full-size pickup trucks and SUVs, marking the third domestic supply contract the automaker has signed related to the critical trade dominated by China. The latest agreement and two others with Las Vegas-based MP Materials Corp. and E-Vac Magnetics, a South Carolina-based unit of Germany's Vacuumschmelze GmbH will allow GM to get the majority of rare-earth magnets it sources directly from domestic suppliers, the Detroit carmaker said Wednesday. Dr Gracelin Baskaran, Director, Critical Minerals Security Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, says the United States is giving all the right signals.

headline: What US consumers can expect from new tariffs on imported goods
summary: American businesses and consumers soon will have a better idea of how President Donald Trump's foreign trade agenda might affect them now that the United States has imposed higher tariffs on products from dozens of countries.  It’s been nearly 100 years since the nation had an overall import tax rate as high as the one set Thursday.  Meanwhile, a 55% tariff on Chinese-made goods is scheduled to take effect next week if a U.S.-China trade deal is not agreed on before then.

raw.headline: What US consumers can expect from new tariffs on imported goods
raw.summary: American businesses and consumers soon will have a better idea of how President Donald Trump's foreign trade agenda might affect them now that the United States has imposed higher tariffs on products from dozens of countries.  It’s been nearly 100 years since the nation had an overall import tax rate as high as the one set Thursday.  Meanwhile, a 55% tariff on Chinese-made goods is scheduled to take effect next week if a U.S.-China trade deal is not agreed on before then.

headline: GM to import EV batteries from China's CATL, source says
summary: (Reuters) -General Motors will import electric vehicle batteries from Chinese battery giant CATL, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters on Thursday.  The arrangement is a stopgap for GM in the next couple of years as it works to manufacture its own lower-cost batteries made with lithium iron phosphate (LFP) chemistry, the source said.  GM has said that its upcoming Chevrolet Bolt will use LFP technology.

raw.headline: GM to import EV batteries from China's CATL, source says

GM has said that its upcoming Chevrolet Bolt will use LFP technology.

headline: GM, Hyundai join forces to battle rising Chinese rivals
summary: STORY: General Motors and Hyundai are joining forces to battle mounting competition from Chinese rivals.The pair said Wednesday (August 6) that they would develop five vehicles together.Four will be targeted at markets in Central and South America, where Chinese brands have been gaining ground.The other one will be an electric van for the North American market.For GM, the deal offers access to hybrid technology that it has lacked.For South Korean Hyundai, it’s a first-ever partnership on vehicle development and offers a way into new markets, including American vans.The two companies didn’t say where the models will be made.Hyundai already has a factory in Alabama and has promised to ramp up output at another plant in Georgia.It also has a factory in Brazil that could be used.The tie-up comes as Chinese brands release a slew of low-priced, high-tech models, pressuring legacy names like GM to cut costs in return.Donald Trump’s sweeping global tariffs have also added billions in costs, increasing pressure to take action.South Korea last week agreed to a 15% levy on its exports to the U.S. as part of a deal with Washington.

raw.headline: GM, Hyundai join forces to battle rising Chinese rivals
raw.summary: STORY: General Motors and Hyundai are joining forces to battle mounting competition from Chinese rivals.The pair said Wednesday (August 6) that they would develop five vehicles together.Four will be targeted at markets in Central and South America, where Chinese brands have been gaining ground.The other one will be an electric van for the North American market.For GM, the deal offers access to hybrid technology that it has lacked.For South Korean Hyundai, it’s a first-ever partnership on vehicle development and offers a way into new markets, including American vans.The two companies didn’t say where the models will be made.Hyundai already has a factory in Alabama and has promised to ramp up output at another plant in Georgia.It also has a factory in Brazil that could be used.The tie-up comes as Chinese brands release a slew of low-priced, high-tech models, pressuring legacy names like GM to cut costs in return.Donald Trump’s sweeping global tariffs have also added billions in costs, increasing pressure to take action.South Korea last week agreed to a 15% levy on its exports to the U.S. as part of a deal with Washington.
